options.content: * Code * Issues * Pull requests * Discussions * Actions * Insights

panels.description:
This chart shows the main metrics about Open PRs.

When comparing the numbers within an interval it is interesting to check the "Difference" value. Negative values are usually good and mean the queue is getting smaller in the specific interval. Positive values may indicate that PRs are taking too long to be reviewed and merged or the community is getting more active.
panels.title: Open PRs Summary

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Active and Inactive PRs, which are PRs without updates within the last 15 days.

In general it is not good to have Inactive PRs in the project. Maintainers should check them. It is possible that a contributor is waiting for a feedback or an unsolved discussion needs intervention and final decision from a maintainer.

The Draft PRs are not considered Inactive PRs in this context because they are usually expected to be outdated. It is a common practice that authors set their PRs to draft when something is still pending but the author does not expected to work on it soon.
panels.title: PRs Activity

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Active and Inactive PRs filed by Team members, including eventual Draft PRs. Inactive PRs are PRs without updates within the last 15 days.

Ping a colleague if your PR is too long waiting review. If you have an inactive Draft PR, consider to close it or to provide a short update about your plans to work on it.
panels.title: Team PRs Activity

panels.description:
This pie chart shows how the Open PRs are distributed based on authors.

These metrics are good to better understand how balanced are the collaboration in the project. But they should not be analysed alone.

In general, all team members are also project maintainers. So it is natural to have more collaboration among team members reflecting in better quality code and consequently faster reviews. Therefore, it is expected that most of the Open PRs comes from the Community.

These number can be better contextualized by analyzing the other charts, specially the ones about Products and Standards distribuition.
panels.title: PRs Source

panels.description:
This chart shows the lifetime average of Open PRs but also provides the same metric for closed PRs within the last 30 and 90 days.

It is usually not good when the Open PRs lifetime average increases. It may indicate that more attention is needed from maintainers in order to review open PRs and allow the authors to move forward. The context should be clarified.

It is good to compare the lifetime of Open PRs with closed PRs within the last 30 and 90 days to find patterns and trends. Ideally, the three metrics should have similar and small values.
panels.title: PRs Lifetime Average

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Assigned and Unassigned PRs, except for Draft PRs.

In general it is not good to have many Unassigned PRs in the project. Maintainers should assign themselves to Unassigned PRs or delegate an assignee to review and allow the PR to move forward.

If you are not comfortable to assign the PR for yourself or delegate an assignee, you can still help by triaging the PR and including proper labels. It will make it easier to other maintainers to collaborate.

The Draft PRs are not considered Inactive PRs in this context because they are usually not expecting reviews.
panels.title: PRs Assigning Rate

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Assigned and Unassigned PRs filed by Team members, including eventual Draft PRs.

In general it is not good to have many Unassigned PRs in the project. Be nice with your colleagues and assign yourself to their Unassigned PRs and help to sucessfully finish it.

If you are not comfortable to assign the PR for yourself or delegate an assignee, you can still help by triaging the PR and including proper labels. It will make it easier to other maintainers to collaborate.
panels.title: Team PRs Assigning Rate

panels.description:
This chart shows the main metrics about Open Issues.

When comparing the numbers within an interval it is interesting to check the "Difference" value. Negative values are usually good and mean the queue is getting smaller in the specific interval. Positive values may indicate that Issues are taking too long to be reviewed and resolved.

Peaks might also indicate more serious issues in a specific release or profile.
panels.title: Open Issues Summary

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Active and Inactive Issues, which are Issues without updates within the last 15 days.

In general it is not good to have Inactive Issues in the project. Maintainers should check them. It is possible that a contributor or customer is waiting for a feedback or a decision from a maintainer.
panels.title: Issues Activity

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Active and Inactive Issues filed by Team members. Inactive Issues are those without updates within the last 15 days.

Ping a colleague if your Issue is too long waiting a feedback. If you have an inactive Issue, consider to close it or to provide a short update about your plans to work on it.
panels.title: Team Issues Activity

panels.description:
This pie chart shows how the Open Issues are distributed based on authors.

These metrics are good to better understand how balanced are the collaboration in the project. But they should not be analysed alone.
panels.title: Issues Source

panels.description:
This chart shows the lifetime average of Open Issues but also provides the same metric for closed Issues within the last 30 and 90 days.

It is usually not good when the Open Issues lifetime average increases. It may indicate that more attention is needed from maintainers in order to review and resolve open Issues.

It is good to compare the lifetime of Open Issues with closed Issues within the last 30 and 90 days to find patterns and trends. Ideally, the three metrics should have similar and small values.
panels.title: Issues Lifetime Average

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Assigned and Unassigned Issues.

In general it is not good to have many Unassigned Issues in the project. Maintainers should assign themselves to Unassigned Issues or delegate an assignee to better investigate the Issue.

If you are not comfortable to assign the Issue for yourself or delegate an assignee, you can still help by triaging the Issue and including proper labels. It will make it easier to other maintainers to collaborate.
panels.title: Issues Assigning Rate

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Assigned and Unassigned Issues.

In general it is not good to have many Unassigned Issues in the project. Maintainers should assign themselves to Unassigned Issues or delegate an assignee to better investigate the Issue.

If you are not comfortable to assign the Issue for yourself or delegate an assignee, you can still help by triaging the Issue and including proper labels. It will make it easier to other maintainers to collaborate.
panels.title: Team Issues Assigning Rate

panels.description:
This chart shows the proportion of PRs created and closed in the last 30 days.

It is interesting to identify trends. If the difference in Created PRs is positive, it could indicate that project activity is increasing and this is likely related to a relevant context, such as a Benchmark update, new contributors, a team task force, etc.

It is also interesting to identify necessary actions. For example, if the average Closed PRs is lower than the Created PRs for a long time, maintainers should take actions to change this. Ideally, the Created and Closed means should be equal.
panels.title: PRs Balance Last 30 Days

panels.description:
This status represents the result of the number of PRs created minus the number of PRs closed in 30 days.

- A negative result is Great.
- A positive result up to 5 is OK.
- A positive result higher than 5 is Not Good.
panels.title: Status

panels.description:
This trend is defined based on the difference of  result of the number of PRs created minus the number of PRs closed in 30 days.

- A negative result means it is Getting Better.
- A positive result up to 3 means it is Stable.
- A positive result higher than 3 means it is Getting Worse.
panels.title: Creation Trend

panels.description:
This trend is defined based on the difference of  result of the number of PRs created minus the number of PRs closed in 30 days.

- A positive result higher than 3 means it is Getting Better.
- A positive result up to 3 means it is Stable.
- A negative result means it is Getting Worse.
panels.title: Closing Trend

panels.description:
This chart shows the proportion of PRs created and closed in the last 90 days.

It is interesting to identify trends. If the difference in Created PRs is positive, it could indicate that project activity is increasing and this is likely related to a relevant context, such as a Benchmark update, new contributors, a team task force, etc.

It is also interesting to identify necessary actions. For example, if the average Closed PRs is lower than the Created PRs for a long time, maintainers should take actions to change this. Ideally, the Created and Closed means should be equal.
panels.title: PRs Balance Last 90 Days

panels.description:
This chart shows the proportion of Issues created and closed in the last 30 days.

It is interesting to identify trends. If the difference in Created Issues is positive, it could indicate that some recent change had side effects or better quality tests were implemented.

It is also interesting to identify necessary actions. For example, if the average Closed Issues is lower than the Created Issues for a long time, maintainers should take actions to change this. Ideally, the Created and Closed means should be equal.
panels.title: Issues Balance Last 30 Days

panels.description:
This status represents the result of the number of Issues created minus the number of Issues closed in 30 days.

- A negative result is Great.
- A positive result up to 5 is OK.
- A positive result higher than 5 is Not Good.
panels.title: Status

panels.description:
This trend is defined based on the difference of  result of the number of Issues created minus the number of Issues closed in 30 days.

- A negative result means it is Getting Better.
- A positive result up to 3 means it is Stable.
- A positive result higher than 3 means it is Getting Worse.
panels.title: Creation Trend

panels.description:
This trend is defined based on the difference of  result of the number of Issues created minus the number of Issues closed in 30 days.

- A positive result higher than 3 means it is Getting Better.
- A positive result up to 3 means it is Stable.
- A negative result means it is Getting Worse.
panels.title: Closing Trend

panels.description:
This chart shows the proportion of Issues created and closed in the last 90 days.

It is interesting to identify trends. If the difference in Created Issues is positive, it could indicate that some recent change had side effects or better quality tests were implemented.

It is also interesting to identify necessary actions. For example, if the average Closed Issues is lower than the Created Issues for a long time, maintainers should take actions to change this. Ideally, the Created and Closed means should be equal.
panels.title: Issues Balance Last 90 Days

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Open PRs related to specific Products.

These metrics are interesting to have some idea about activity related to specific products. Peaks might indicate benchmark updates, new profiles, new products, etc.

It is always good to investigate the context of peaks. It is common to find opportunities of collaboration among different products regarding coverage.
panels.title: PRs by Products

panels.description:
This chat shows the distribution history of Open PRs related to specific Products.

These metrics are interesting to have some idea about activity related to specific products. Peaks might indicate benchmark updates, new profiles, new products, etc.

It is always good to investigate the context of peaks. It is common to find opportunities of collaboration among different products regarding coverage. This history can also reveal similarities among products.
panels.title: History of PRs by Products

panels.description:
This chart shows the history of PRs and Issues based on some relevant labels.

The numbers include both Issues and PRs.

These metrics are interesting to identify patterns and peaks of specific Issues or PRs.
panels.title: Other Relevant Labels

panels.description:
This pie chat shows the distribution of Open PRs related to specific Standards.

These metrics are interesting to have some idea about activity related to specific standards. Peaks might indicate benchmark updates, new profiles, new rules, etc.

It is always good to investigate the context of peaks. It is common to find opportunities of collaboration among different products regarding standards coverage.
panels.title: PRs by Standards

panels.description:
This chat shows the distribution history of Open PRs related to specific Standards.

These metrics are interesting to have some idea about activity related to specific standards. Peaks might indicate benchmark updates, new profiles, new rules, etc.

It is always good to investigate the context of peaks. It is common to find opportunities of collaboration among different products regarding standards coverage.
panels.title: History of PRs by Standards

panels.description:
This chart shows the history of PRs and Issues based on some relevant labels.

The numbers include both Issues and PRs.

These metrics are interesting to identify patterns and peaks of specific Issues or PRs.
panels.title: History of Check and Remediation
